Created a simplified UI framework for several other legacy WinForms apps. This allowed me to work on 3 total revamps with 3 back end developers simultaneously over the course of 1 month in a war-room setting.

Among my proudest achievements, as I was able to develop an algorithm for generating PDFs containing variable length detailed lists of products resulting in a uniform appearance without failing into an infinite loop.

history.name: SaltSquares LLC
history.title: Managing Member, Founder
history.description:
SaltSquares was a spinoff from a Startup Weekend event in Detroit held in May 2010 for which I became the founder, managing member and lead developer with 6 others. The concept won first place for the event and centered around a mobile app incorporating hyper-locality, QR Codes, referrals, rewards, and social media.It was FourSquare meets Groupon on steroids.

Unfortunately the bootstraps broke a few months later before a completed platform was ready to secure a first round of funding.

The knowledge gained was immeasurable. In hindsight, and given where we currently are with user data privacy, it's early demise was probably for the best.
details: Using a fairly new platform called Appcelerator, and working closely with its founder, I had created iPhone and Android prototypes within the first month.
Ann Arbor New Tech presentation
2010 1st annual Maker Fair at Henry Ford

Inspired and facilitated the adoption of Agile methodologies.
Performed as Scrum Master and UX/UI developer for the creation of a custom CMS.
Developed and launched a client-facing website.

Built the 30 Year Fixed website - A step-by-step Q&A app that results in a quote on a mortgage rate.

Developed a Mortgage Rate Widget for use on sites like Yahoo, Google and MSN.

Side: Created several Google Maps mash-ups and mobile app prototypes.
Side: Introduced agile methodologies to QL providing several Lunch & Learns that quickly won over the CTO and Dev VP.

history.name: Sircon
history.title: Web Developer, UI Lead
history.description: Sircon, acquired by Vertafore, provides software solutions for the insurance industry at state, local, and agent levels.
details: Lead the effort to refactor all legacy client-side code using W3C Web standards to speed up content delivery and enhance accessibility and usability.
Built a scalable standards-based front-end architecture to support a team of 20+ developers.
Via workshops and one-on-one mentoring, taught proper document structure, layout, and presentation techniques using semantic markup and CSS.
Created several tools and ad hoc POCs to assist with requirements gathering, project management, application and UI development.

Designed and Developed the Sircon Corporate Web site based on usability testing results of the original site. As a result, Web site related support calls were reduced by nearly 80%. To be fair, the original was pretty bad.
Assisted with client pre-sales and requirements gathering for Aflac and One America.

Created a detailed roadmap for an application UI/usability improvement strategy and drafted a web UI Development spec, including the identification of key areas for surgical strike improvements in older Web applications.

Designed the UI and oversaw its integration for Producer Express (now WorkSmartâ„¢ by Vertafore). This Web application is completely skin-able and brand-able, using role based workflows to expedite the collection of digital signatures. My design and storyboarding process is the primary reason for its overwhelming success and turn-around time. This application reduced a months-long agent onboarding process to mere hours for insurance organizations.
Virtually eliminated the need for java developers to think about the UI by encapsulating nearly all elements within pulsar libraries.

history.name: ThyssenKrupp
history.title: Web Development Contractor
history.description: The Budd Company was a 20th-century metal fabricator, a major supplier of body components to the automobile industry, and a manufacturer of stainless steel passenger rail cars,[2] airframes, missile and space vehicles, and various defense products.
details: Created gadgets (portlets, applications) for TKBudd's Plumtree Portal, US Body Division. All applications were created by me with ASP, SQL Server, and DHTML. Highlights include:

Open Issues Gadget - Logging, management, and reporting of issues within a hierarchy of programs and projects for multiple roles with varying degrees of security. Project teams were created and managed from a pool of employees, customers and suppliers. All data could be exported to XL for offline use and returned via the browser. There was also a Lessons Learned module for post-project QA.

Executive Report Gadget - On a weekly basis, departments and plants report on several aspects of general operation. At the end of the week these reports are edited by the executive assistant for presentation to the CEO via this application.

Daily Field Reporting Gadget - All plants provided daily reports for QA concerning specifics on production I/O as well as defects, their cause and responsibility. Reports and graphs were then generated from this data using XL templates.

history.name: Borders
history.title: Web Designer
history.description: Borders Group, Inc. was an international book and music retailer based in Ann Arbor, Michigan. In its final year, the company employed about 19,500 people throughout the U.S., primarily in its Borders and Waldenbooks stores.
details: Redesigned and developed the BGI Corporate Web site including portions of the site hosted by two separate vendors using Javascript for templating.
Facilitated the design and production of all Internet and email promotions for the new find out| BORDERS campaign as well as numerous Waldenbooks-Brentano's email ads.
Fulfilled countless ad hoc requests for graphics and coding for other development groups on projects including the Title Sleuth in-store kiosk.

Unsuccessfully tried to pitch the following: Rather than use the in-store kiosks for providing a kludgy search buried within way more marketing than an individual that is already in the store needs, what if we looked at ways to embrace digital media and perhaps pilot burning custom CDs with user selected content? I even made a prototype. I tried, Borders... I tried. We all know the rest of that story.

history.description: Since 2001, Menlo has pursued returning joy to technology. Their mission is to end human suffering in the world as it relates to technology.

history.name: Tumbleweed Communications
history.title: Application Engineer II
history.description: Tumbleweed Communications Corp. provided secure messaging and secure file transfer solutions for enterprise and government customers. Tumbleweed Communications merged with Axway in 2008.
details: Rewrote the Secure Messenger software UI simultaneously with a custom ASP app that allowed sales engineers the ability to create client-branded demos. The parameters used in the sales demo could then be easily intigrated as part of the template for production. This work essentially reduced a 1-2 month development cycle to less than 2 weeks, and in some instances, merely one day.

As a Professional Services consultant, I customized and branded the Secure Messenger product for many of their clients including: Chase Private Bank, JPMorgan, JPMorgan-Chase, Mutual of Omaha, Diners Club, Pitney Bowes, and the US Postal Service.
Authored product documentation.
Provided on-site client training.

history.name: Interface Systems Inc.
history.title: Senior Web Developer/Designer
history.description: Acquired by Tumbleweed in 2002, Interface primarily made printer boards that parsed print streams into a database allowing financial institutions legacy document conversion capabilities (L2I: Legacy to Internet) to better compete with the likes of eTrade.
details: Redesigned the corporate Web site and the Cleo Communications subsidiary website.

Developed HTML/CSS prototypes of financial paper statements and confirms for several clients of ADP including National Discount Brokerage, ABN-AMRO, Wachovia, Legg Mason, and Discover Brokerage. These HTML documents were required to be as faithful as possible to their printed counterparts in accordance with SiPC regulations.

Once acquired by Tumbleweed, roughly half of the 120 employees were let go with a healthy severance, including myself. I was rehired within 2 months after their product manager found out about the side project I had been working on for Secure Messenger (detailed previously) prior to the downsizing.

history.name: St. Vincent Medical Center

Found out Web Development pays much better... and is way more fun!

history.name: US Navy
history.title: Hospital Corpsman, Petty Officer Third Class
details: Hospital Corpsman Program
Certified Surgical Technician (Associate's Degree equiv.)
Emergency Medical Technician (NREMT)
CPR and AED Instructor
Awarded: National Defense Service Merit, Sea Service Deployment Ribbon, Good Conduct, Southwest Asia Service Medal, Unit Citation
Served 2 years on the USS George Washington aircraft carrier (CVN-73)
Honorably Discharged
Inactive Reserves for 4 additional years

objective:
To create simple, seamless experiences, valuing the user above all else. You know, what everyone's objective should be.

The creation of any product, software or otherwise, is pointless and will suffer in value if its interface is hindering in any way. We already have the ability to produce flawless code on the back end. The UI is the final frontier. It's where the real challenges lie. Its creation demands the most of anticipation, creativity, and simplicity. Understanding the needs and expectations of every person or thing that interacts with it, providing the optimal response without introducing any cause or pause for question.

I can't think of any discipline more exciting, challenging, rewarding, or fun than this. It's also cool to say that I get to bend light to my will. And whether it's me or someone else that's got you covered here, at least know that if you don't have someone like me, then whatever it is that you're trying to achieve will fall far short of its goals.
summary:
• Research, understand, and hold users as my top priority, knowing that any feedback whatsoever requires some level of consideration toward improving the experience or outcome.
  • While I can easily knock out simple wireframes, use cases, and workflows, I can prototype just as quickly, integrating the afore mentioned, and provide a UI that's readily usable and adaptable for production.
  • I start out objectively, applying well-established UI/UX design patterns. The creativity comes as a second pass to enhance media-specific norms as required by branding, user research, and getting an edge on the competition.
  • Understanding that HTML is a data source, I semantically structure and maintain its integrity on the client. To elaborate, I usually follow this up by asking if it makes sense to name DB table columns: column1, column2, column3... Of course not, and that's akin to abusing spans, divs, or any markup available that doesn't best contextualize its contained content/data. I can talk/teach at great length on this topic BTW.
  • Magic. This word has been used many times, by several people.

education.name: US Navy
education.location: Great Lakes, IL | Pensacola, FL | Bethesda, MD | Norfolk, VA | USS George Washington (CVN-73)
education.description:
Anyone with military experience knows that the level of adaptability, trainabilty, and attention to detail we posess is beyond compare. We have mottos like "see one, do one, teach one", "always have a backup", "whatever, whenever, wherever", "no limits, no excuses".

Bootcamp provided me with this foundation for everything I've done and learned since.
education.degree: Honorable Discharge, Petty Officer 3rd Class, Certified Surgical Assistant (Associate's Equivalent), NR-EMT, CPR Instructor
education.awards: National Defense Service Merit, Sea Service Deployment Ribbon, Good Conduct, Southwest Asia Service Medal, Unit Citation.

education.name: Life
education.description:
In 1997 bought a PC, hopped on AOL, and decided to attempt creating a website for a cover band I was in. I became immediately hooked by the ability to bend pixels to my will. Within 1 year I was offered a position at a small marketing agency and left my career in medicine.

Since then, everything I know has come from the Internet. I had considered pursuing a relevant degree, but there was nothing on offer anywhere near what I had already learned on my own. The time, effort and cost associated with obtaining a degree has held, and continues to hold no value for me. And to date I have yet to hear a compelling argument why in this line of work I should think otherwise.

He brought a level of energy and passion to his work that is hard to match and was a pleasure to work with. He is creative and constantly looking for a better way to do things. He would be an asset to any team looking for a highly creative frontend developer.

Prior to Vertafore we also worked for Interface Systems, I was impressed enough with Jeff to recommend him for his position at Sircon (subsequently acquired by Vertafore). Jeff is passionate about the advantages of new trends in methodology and technology, and dedicated to helping colleagues to take advantage of industry advances.

When it comes to html, css, and javascript, Jeff is definitely your guy!  Before I met him I was less than a beginner when it came to front-end work, but Jeff showed me the ropes and was a great inspiration.

recommendations.name: Rob Whall
recommendations.title: Owner
recommendations.text: I readily recommend Jeff. He is a very talented and creative web designer who has never failed to amaze me. I have worked with Jeff on several projects at different companies and would do so again in a heartbeat. He has that rare combination of an eye for design as well as intuitive usability that makes his creations both visually stunning and a joy to use.

recommendations.text: Jeff always thought outside of the box and was always coming up with creative ideas. He was instrumental in helping us push Agile programming methodologies into the company. Great guy, easy to work with, a great thinker.

intro.head: TMI...
intro.body:
Personally, I would skip this little introduction and only return to it if I was impressed by this little showcase or had more questions about its creator's skills or process. The additional context I provide here can easily be applied before or after.

...

TMI stands for Too Much Information, and that's exactly what lies beyond this modal. To be clear: THIS is the portfolio. The content therein just happens to be my professional history.

You're probably here because you've either seen my 1-page resumé and would like to see more, or I referred you here due to a lack of code & design samples from the last several years. Long story short, it involved an urgent need for a bootable macOS thumbdrive, and a prior large file purge from Google Drive.

You could also call this a 1-week personal coding challenge. My only goal starting out was to get something out there to look at. I had no design planned, other than to create something interesting using semantic markup (barely any divs or spans - as it should be) and a few popular frameworks/APIs, and magic tricks. Currently there are only 2 themes. One is quite basic with very little styling, and the other resembles an Agile board. I will be adding drastically different themes that only modify the CSS - leaving the base markup intact.

Warning: If you've never done Agile (and properly), what you're about to see may scare you, and my design choices may seem questionable. Otherwise, I think you'll dig this. I also welcome any questions concerning my design, accessibility and interaction choices. However, the answer to many of them will likely be that I did all of this in 1 week!

A few more thoughts before you continue:

The primary takeaway (at this point in time) should be speed v accuracy.
The vast majority of this took place from Feb 4th - Mar 2nd, 2020. Unless or until this introduction is updated to guarantee the quality of particular features, this purely reflects my riffing chops.
There are currently several aspects that are incomplete.
There may be missing or incomplete content, something may not look right on a particular device, there's code that isn't production-ready, and likely a few misspeelings (due to my current macbook keyboard issues)... This is currently a flaws-and-all sandbox, undergoing continual refinement.
Want to give me a coding or design challenge?
Bring it on! And if you don't already have something prepared, perhaps adding a new feature/refinement to this project would be suitable.
